nexttext:
Notice that we use the condition $\alpha < 1$ throughout the whole paper and that we adopt the notation $\left<O\right>$ and $\overline O$ to denote ensemble and time average, respectively. We shall adopt the notation 
$\left<\overline O\right>$ to denote ensemble averages of time averages. 

The result of Eq. (\ref{definition}) found in Ref. \cite{reference} is based on the  model of anomalous diffusion, called Continuous Time Random Walk (CTRW) \cite{ctrw}.  In this paper we interpret CTRW using the metaphor of a random walker making her jumps of intensity $\xi$ in the \emph{psychological time}, with the values $\xi$ randomly selected from a Gaussian distribution. In the literature the psychological time is usually denoted as operational time. The adoption of the term of psychological time is mainly motivated by our wish of explaining the results of this article with intuitive arguments, even if the adoption of the concept of subjective time turned out to be useful to explain the emergence of an inverse power law to connect the psychological time to the clock time \cite{psychologicaltime}. Actually, in the clock time the distance between two consecutive values of $\xi$, with vanishing values in between,  
is selected from a distribution density $\psi(\tau)$ with the time asymptotic property

The same kind of dependence on the length of the time series was found also in the power spectrum $P(f)$ of the renewal generators of sub-diffusion \cite{margolin,mirko},

with $0 < \delta < 1$. This correlation function is not integrable, thereby making the correlation time infinite.
This is a generalization of the CTRW and the main result of this paper is that the joint action of renewal events 
with diverging mean waiting time and infinite correlation time of the fluctuation $\xi$ generates localization. 

To stress the special nature of non-Poisson renewal  processes it is convenient to mention another form of ergodicity-breaking  process, called Scaled Brownian Motion
(SBM) \cite{sum}. This form of anomalous diffusion is attracting an increasing  interest  by the researchers working on anomalous diffusion in biological cells \cite{review,scaledfbm,safdari,bodrova}. 
The SBM \cite{scaledfbm}
generates the fluctuation $\xi(t)$ according to the prescription

This is a generalization of the CTRW and the main result of this paper is that the joint action of renewal events 
with diverging mean waiting time and infinite correlation time of the fluctuation $\xi$ generates localization. 

To stress the special nature of non-Poisson renewal  processes it is convenient to mention another form of ergodicity-breaking  process, called Scaled Brownian Motion
(SBM) \cite{sum}. This form of anomalous diffusion is attracting an increasing  interest  by the researchers working on anomalous diffusion in biological cells \cite{review,scaledfbm,safdari,bodrova}. 
The SBM \cite{scaledfbm}
generates the fluctuation $\xi(t)$ according to the prescription

nexttext:
As earlier mentioned, the ergodicity breaking makes the results of the time average depend on the length $L$ of the time sequence, through the factor $1/L^{1-\alpha}$ of Eq. (\ref{definition}) and Eq. (\ref{true1/f}). The function
$1/L^{1-\alpha}$ is not integrable, thereby making it possible to observe these effects in spite of  $L$ being extremely large. 

It is known that SBM yields a form of exceptionally slow diffusion in the special case \cite{bodrova} where $D(t) \propto t^{2H-1} \propto 1/t$, corresponding to $H=0$ and consequently to sub-diffusion. 
In this paper we shall discuss the joint action of NPR events and SBM and we shall prove that this joint action leads to a dependence on $L$ given by
$1/L^{\gamma}$, where $\gamma$ may become larger than $1$, with the effect of totally annihilating the manifestation of randomness, namely, with the effect of generating a \emph{perfect localization}. 
Quite surprisingly we find localization also in the opposite case of $H \rightarrow 1$, as an effect, this time, of the joint action of the NPR events and the well known fractional Brownian motion (FBM). We want to observe that this is a consequence of the different nature of FBM and SBM. In fact, this paper rests on the theoretical perspective of FBM discussed in Ref. \cite{cakir,arkady},
where the scaling index $H \rightarrow 1$ corresponds to the infinite memory of fluctuation $\xi$, with no random events, and this lack of random events  has the impressive effect of completely suppressing the manifestation of intermittent randomness.

It is known that SBM yields a form of exceptionally slow diffusion in the special case \cite{bodrova} where $D(t) \propto t^{2H-1} \propto 1/t$, corresponding to $H=0$ and consequently to sub-diffusion. 
In this paper we shall discuss the joint action of NPR events and SBM and we shall prove that this joint action leads to a dependence on $L$ given by
$1/L^{\gamma}$, where $\gamma$ may become larger than $1$, with the effect of totally annihilating the manifestation of randomness, namely, with the effect of generating a \emph{perfect localization}. 
Quite surprisingly we find localization also in the opposite case of $H \rightarrow 1$, as an effect, this time, of the joint action of the NPR events and the well known fractional Brownian motion (FBM). We want to observe that this is a consequence of the different nature of FBM and SBM. In fact, this paper rests on the theoretical perspective of FBM discussed in Ref. \cite{cakir,arkady},
where the scaling index $H \rightarrow 1$ corresponds to the infinite memory of fluctuation $\xi$, with no random events, and this lack of random events  has the impressive effect of completely suppressing the manifestation of intermittent randomness.

$\tau_{\psi}$.

For $\gamma < 1$ the time scale $\tau_c$, which should be positive,
 becomes negative, this being a consequence of the fact that 
 for $\gamma < 1$ Eq. (\ref{onlypsi>1}) is not more valid and $\tau_c = \infty$.  
 On the basis of these remarks we conclude that the quantities described by Eq. (\ref{definition}) and Eq. (\ref{true1/f}) are experimentally observable, because regardless of how large $L$ is,  $\gamma = 1 - \alpha < 1$, making the observability scale infinite in  those cases. 
 
 \section{First form of joint action of different sources of sub-diffusion} \label{clock}
 
 The first form of joint action of two different sources of anomalous 
diffusion  discussed in this article rests on the extension of CTRW, where the runner sees in her psychological time random events,  to the case where the jumps made by the runner in her psychological time are correlated, as a consequence  of the infinite memory of the FBM generating fluctuations.  In other words, we imagine that the runner in her psychological time $t_{\psi}$ makes a diffusion described by FBM  and in the clock time $t$ the runner does not change her coordinate $x$ if no renewal event occurs. 
 This has the effect of producing  the time scale dilatation
prevtext: which,  for $u = 0$,  reads

nexttext: and a proper graphical representation requires the trajectory $x(t)$to be compressed by multiplying time by the squeezing factor
prevtext:
For $\gamma < 1$ the time scale $\tau_c$, which should be positive,
 becomes negative, this being a consequence of the fact that 
 for $\gamma < 1$ Eq. (\ref{onlypsi>1}) is not more valid and $\tau_c = \infty$.  
 On the basis of these remarks we conclude that the quantities described by Eq. (\ref{definition}) and Eq. (\ref{true1/f}) are experimentally observable, because regardless of how large $L$ is,  $\gamma = 1 - \alpha < 1$, making the observability scale infinite in  those cases. 
 
 \section{First form of joint action of different sources of sub-diffusion} \label{clock}
 
 The first form of joint action of two different sources of anomalous 
diffusion  discussed in this article rests on the extension of CTRW, where the runner sees in her psychological time random events,  to the case where the jumps made by the runner in her psychological time are correlated, as a consequence  of the infinite memory of the FBM generating fluctuations.  In other words, we imagine that the runner in her psychological time $t_{\psi}$ makes a diffusion described by FBM  and in the clock time $t$ the runner does not change her coordinate $x$ if no renewal event occurs. 
 This has the effect of producing  the time scale dilatation
and a proper graphical representation requires the trajectory $x(t)$to be compressed by multiplying time by the squeezing factor

In this paper to generate the trajectory $x(t)$ yielding the fluctuation $\xi(t)$ we use the algorithm of Ref. \cite{misraelvis}. This not only allows us to establish an approach
equivalent to the dynamical approach to FBM of the earlier work of Refs. \cite{cakir,arkady} but it also makes it possible for us to make a comparison with SBM of Eq. (\ref{prescriptionofsokolov}). After recording $\xi(t)$ 
we evaluate its correlation function using the time average and, resting on the ergodicity property,  we establish numerically the parameter $T_B$  of Eq. (\ref{correlation1}) and the mean quadratic value $\left<\xi^2\right>$.

nexttext:
This formula for $\alpha=1$ shows that FBM is ergodic.
If $\alpha < 1$, the cascade of Feller events makes the intensity of diffusion coefficient depend on the time length of the sequence, thereby generating ergodicity breaking without changing the scaling of FBM. When $H = 0.5$ this formula becomes identical to Eq. (\ref{definition}), namely the theoretical proposal of Ref. \cite{reference}.
Note also that on the basis of the remarks of Section \ref{integrability} 
this formula holds true under the condition

nexttext:
To establish a real limit to the bottom value of $\alpha$ we  set the condition
$H > 0.5$ and 
the FBM generated by the fluctuations perceived by the runner in her psychological time should produce super-diffusion, but the transition from the psychological to the clock time scale has the dramatic effect of generating localization when $\alpha < \alpha_c$. 

This theoretical prediction is satisfactorily supported by the numerical  calculations of Fig. \ref{rohisha}. The
analytical prediction of Eq. (\ref{moreconvenient}) breaks 
in the vicinity of $\gamma = 1$ due to to divergence of this formula at this critical value. However, the numerical 
calculation shows that, as predicted by the theory of Section \ref{integrability}, the second moment $\overline{\delta^2}(\Delta)$ vanishes for $\gamma > 1$. 

 
 \begin{figure*}[ht]
\centering
\includegraphics[width= 180mm]{mekla1_new.png}
 \caption{The red triangles denote $\left<\overline{\delta^2}(\Delta)\right>$ of Eq. (\ref{moreconvenient}) as a function of $\gamma$ given by Eq. (\ref{definitionofgamma}). $H = 0.75$, $\Delta = 10^3$. To define Eq. (\ref{definitionofgamma}) we use  Eq. (\ref{definitionofc}), Eq. (\ref{valueofA}), Eq. (\ref{valueofB}) and $a = B^{1/\gamma}$. The black squares show the result of numerical treatment. For details on the numerical values adopted please see Section \ref{smile}.}
\label{rohisha}\end{figure*}




\subsection{Details on the numerical calculation} \label{smile}

We set $H = 0.75$, thereby yielding $\delta =  0.5$, and according to Eq. \ref{criticalvalueofalpha}, establishing the critical value for $\alpha$, $\alpha_c = 0.3333$.
The fitting value of $T_B$ of Eq. (\ref{correlation2}) for $H = 0.75$ is $T_B =  0.129$ thereby leading us to select for $T$ of Eq. (\ref{manneville}) the value $T =  0.091$.  The mean quadratic value of $\xi$ for $H = 0.75$ is $\left<\xi^2\right> = 0.0657$. The value of $c$ is given by Eq. (\ref{definitionofc}) and with the earlier values of $T_B$, $H$ and $\delta$ turns out to be $c=0.0627$. The value of $A$ is given by Eq. (\ref{valueofA}) and it changes with $\alpha$ making also the value of $B$ of Eq. (\ref{valueofB}),  and of $a = B^{1/\gamma}$  as well,  change with $\alpha$. In the whole region
explored from $\alpha = 1$ to $\alpha =  0.3333$, the parameter $a$ remains smaller than $1$. 
To support this prediction with numerical results we  set

This theoretical prediction is satisfactorily supported by the numerical  calculations of Fig. \ref{rohisha}. The

\subsection{Details on the numerical calculation} \label{smile}

We set $H = 0.75$, thereby yielding $\delta =  0.5$, and according to Eq. \ref{criticalvalueofalpha}, establishing the critical value for $\alpha$, $\alpha_c = 0.3333$.
The fitting value of $T_B$ of Eq. (\ref{correlation2}) for $H = 0.75$ is $T_B =  0.129$ thereby leading us to select for $T$ of Eq. (\ref{manneville}) the value $T =  0.091$.  The mean quadratic value of $\xi$ for $H = 0.75$ is $\left<\xi^2\right> = 0.0657$. The value of $c$ is given by Eq. (\ref{definitionofc}) and with the earlier values of $T_B$, $H$ and $\delta$ turns out to be $c=0.0627$. The value of $A$ is given by Eq. (\ref{valueofA}) and it changes with $\alpha$ making also the value of $B$ of Eq. (\ref{valueofB}),  and of $a = B^{1/\gamma}$  as well,  change with $\alpha$. In the whole region
explored from $\alpha = 1$ to $\alpha =  0.3333$, the parameter $a$ remains smaller than $1$. 
To support this prediction with numerical results we  set

nexttext:
The purpose of this prescription is to go as close as possible to the criticality divergence while remaining 
in the region where $\tau_c$ is finite.  We set $\epsilon = 0.00005$. This yields  $\tau_c < 2\cdot10^4$. 
We set $L = 10^6$ and as consequence 
even when go extremely close to the critical value $\gamma = 1$, the correlation time $\tau_c$ is much shorter than the length of the time series, thereby 
explaining why the numerical result drops to a vanishing value even before reaching the singularity.

We do not have analytical formulas for 
$\alpha < \alpha_c$, but we believe that our theoretical arguments are strong enough to state that for $\alpha < \alpha_c$ the prediction $\eta = \alpha H$ for ensemble averages keeps holding.

\section{Second form of joint action of renewal and infinite memory} \label{secondform}. 

The second form of joint action is realized by adopting SBM rather than FBM, and by assuming that SBM is activated
in the clock time. The runner, however, spends a large part of her time sleeping. She jumps only when she is awake.

 \caption{(color on line) The ensemble average of the second moment $\left<x^2(t)\right>$ for different values of $H$ and $\alpha$. 
  All the curves were generated from the average of $10^4$ realizations. From the top to the bottom: 
  $H = 0.45, \alpha = 0.9$; $H = 0.45, \alpha = 0.6$; $H = 0.10, \alpha = 0.75$; $H = 0.10, \alpha = 0.5$. All the straight lines but the bottom one are guidelines
  indicating the scaling $2 \eta = (2H-1 + \alpha)$. Note that  for the bottom curve,  corresponding  to $2 \eta = -0.2$, the numerical result fits  the guideline straight curve with vanishing slope. }
\label{mekla2time2}.
\end{figure*}

 
 

Ref. \cite{bologna} does not explain which the dynamics of this process are when 
$\eta < 0$.  As a result of the theoretical approach illustrated in this paper we  reach the compelling conclusion that this negative scaling has the same significance as  the negative waiting time of Eq. (\ref{onlypsi>1}) and the negative value of the second moment of Eq. (\ref{moreconvenient}). In the case of Eq. (\ref{onlypsi>1}), as we have seen in Section \ref{integrability}, this negative value indicates  that the correlation length is infinite and in that of Eq. (\ref{onlypsi>1}), the negative value of the second moment is the signature of a perfect localization, as proved by the theory of this paper, with the support of the numerical results illustrated in Fig. \ref{mekla2time2}. 


In fact,  adopting the average in time rather than the ensemble average, we shall show hereby that the $\left<\overline{\delta^2}(\Delta)\right>$ becomes negative when $\eta < 0$.

a condition of perfect localization occurs, in perfect agreement with the numerical results of Fig. 2, as clearly shown by the purple bottom curve of this figure.

This article affords a solution to the question raised by
the authors of Ref. \cite{bologna} on the interpretation of the scaling generated by the diffusion equation

a condition of perfect localization occurs, in perfect agreement with the numerical results of Fig. 2, as clearly shown by the purple bottom curve of this figure. 





 


 
 
 




   
     
 

  
  
 
 
 


\section{Concluding Remarks} \label{concludingremarks}

This article affords a solution to the question raised by
the authors of Ref. \cite{bologna} on the interpretation of the scaling generated by the diffusion equation

nexttext:
The authors of this article proved that this diffusion equation generates the scaling of Eq. (\ref{crucialscaling}).
An important result of this article is the discovery that the single trajectories corresponding to this scaling are those illustrated in Section \ref{secondform}. The research we did to answer this question led us to establish that the condition $\eta < 0$ corresponds to localization. 
The theoretical explanation of this phenomenon is given by Eq. (\ref{torewrite}). When $\eta < 0$ this second moment becomes negative, this being a compelling 
indication of a strong localization. In fact, when $\gamma > 1$,
in the asymptotic regime of sequences with large values of $L$, due to the integrability of $1/L^{\gamma}$, the randomness induced broadening is totally quenched. 
Although interesting, this result can be easily explained, because the localization effect is obtained when $H < 0.5$ ($H= 0.4$ in the case of Fig. 2). The SBM leads to sub-diffusion and it is not quite surprising that the joint action with the NPR  $\alpha < 1$ leads to localization.

Much more surprising is the result that we obtain thanks to the joint action of NPR and FBM, as illustrated in Fig. 1. In this case the localization induced by ergodicity breaking is realized with $H > 0.5$ corresponding to super-diffusion. We are convinced that this result may lead to a new vision of randomness and order.  To shape this vision it may be convenient to consider FBM with the second moment 
increasing as $t^{2H}$ as a misleading indication of randomness. The correlation function of Eq. (\ref{correlation2}) is compatible with the derivation from 
the Hamilton formalism and consequently with the Laplace determinism. There exists a further, and even more important consequence, this  being that  the entropy increase is due in this case to the lack of information generated by a contraction over the irrelevant variables that, in spite of being ignored, is responsible  for the slow decay of this correlation function. The second moment increasing as $t^{\alpha}$, on the contrary, has a completely different meaning. In the psychological time,
in fact, any time step is characterized by the action of a random event, thereby forcing the second moment to increase  linearly with $\tau_{\psi}$. As a matter of fact, as we have seen, $t^{\alpha} = \tau_{\psi}$. In this case,
when we depart from the singularity condition $H = 0.5$, where $\xi$ is completely uncorrelated, and we move towards $H = 1$ with the decay of the correlation function of Eq. (\ref{correlation2}) becoming slower and slower, the correlated fluctuation $\xi$ has the effect of completely quenching 
the action of NPR randomness at the critical value $H_c = 1/{[2(1-\alpha)]}$. \\
